docs.lead_paragraph: PROSPECTS Of A QUIET TIME.--After the two months of excitements we have just passed through, there is at last a prospect of a very decided calm. Mayor WOOD has left the City for a fortnight; Mrs. CUNNINGHAM has been taken to the Tombs; the two Street Commissioners are in a state of dead lock, without the chance of another certiorari, quo warranto,

headline.main: THE CANADA'S MAILS.; Fifty Regiments of Sepoys in Rebellion. DELHI NOT YET FALLEN. Description of the Recent Battles Between the British and the Chinese. THE CHINA WAR. THE INDIAN MUTINIES. The Great Race for the Goodwood Cup. Highly Interesting Details of News. Victory of" Monarque" Over the English and American Horses.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Canada's mails reached this City from Bos ton at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. We publish below extended details of the important and highly interesting news, of which a telegraphic summary has been received. When within 60 miles of Boston the Canada, on Wednesday evening at 8 o'clock, passed the Europa, outward bound. The steamships saluted each other with rockets in splendid style.

headline.main: NEW-GRANADA AND CENTRAL AMERICA.; Passage of a Law Annulling the Sovereignty of Panama-A Separation of the State from New-Granada Advocated-The United States Government and Central American Affairs-Costa Rica's right in the Transit-Our Minister to GuatemalaMovements of United States War Vessels -Expected Resistance by England to the New-Granadian Tonnage Tax-A National Bank in San Jose, Costa Rica-The Panama Railroad-Departure of the United States Flag-Ship-lnteresting Correspondence.

docs.lead_paragraph: Advices have been received here from Bogota to the 8th ult. Congress had adjourned. Before adjourning, however, the bill that had passed to a third reading in both branches of Congress, providing for the establishment of certain national privileges in this State, a translation of which you received per last steamer, after some unimportant modifications, finally passed and become a law.
docs.abstract: A national Bank in Costa Rica

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; The President at Home--Cabinet Meeting--Naval--Frigates to Sail--Kansas--Indian Affairs. FROM WASHINGTON. By Telegraph to the N. Y. Daily Times. [By the American Telegraph Company's Lines--Office, ?1 Wall st.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The President arrived home, yesterday, in remarkable health. In consequence of the great accumulation of affairs since his absence, an informal meeting of the Cabinet was held immediately. Domestic affairs only were considered. In regular meeting of the Cabinet, to-morrow, the affairs of Granada, Venezuela, and the Mexican Tehuantepec transit will come up and be acted on.

headline.main: QUARANTINE.; Commissioners of Emigration. The Seguine's Point Accommodations Rejected

docs.lead_paragraph: The Commissioners of Emigration met in Worth street on Wednesday afternoon, the President, GULIAN C. VEEPLANCK, Esq., in the Chair. PresentCommissioners PURDY, WILSON G. HUNT, CUMMINGS, CUBTIS, CARRIGAN and GARRIGUR. Documents were received from the Quarantine Commissionore of an interesting and important character.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fort Laramie dates to the 20th ult. have been received. Col. SUMNER had arrived at Bent's Fort, and would leave on the 12th for the head-waters of the Republican Forks, in pursuit of the Cheyennes. The California trains had all passed Fort Laramie in good health.

headline.main: Revaiting--Rape, Incest, and Preparation for Murder.

MRS. CUNNINGHAM.; Proceedings in the Court of General Sessions. A Mysterious Old Woman in Boad-st. THE BABY ON EXHIBITION. Mrs. Cunningham to be Removed to the Tombs. RECORDER SMITH REFUSES BAIL JUDGE DALY REFUSES BAIL Proceedings in the Court of Common Pleas.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cunningham baby case made a decided movement yesterday, and it is now certain that Mrs. CUNNINGHAM will not be admitted to bail. Mr. STAFFORD, her sole surviving counsel, failed in the writ of cartiorart yesterday before Judge DALY, and later in the day he failed equally before Recorder SMITH. It is expected that M. s. CUNNINGHAM will be removed to the City Prison to day.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon President STEARNS delivered the Baccalaureate address to the members of the Graduating Class. His text was taken from the twentieth verse of the second chapter of Galatians, and the discourse was devoted to the consideration of the influence which the spirit of Christ exerted upon the learned professions when it becomes the governing principle of those engaged in the practice of them.
